chapter.name: MaxScore: Graphics
chapter.p: MaxScore users can use the Picster mode to create and edit shapes on the fly.

MaxScore allows you to also attach shapes to measures or staves. This means that a shape will be shown automatically on every part should the score be split or rendered to multiple clients. It’s best used for global instructions that affect every members of an ensemble at once, such as tempo or overall dynamics. By using the canvas blankPageTransform 1 message, you can hide all score elements such as bar lines, clefs or staff lines and create purely graphical scores. The graphics will still have to be attached to either measure or staves whose areas show when clicked on the (now) empty space they usually occupy.
You can set the preference in the following 3 ways:

ul.li: selecting a note / staff / measure in the canvas
pressing s for staff or m for measure after selecting a note
sending messages to the MaxScore abstraction (see the section "Creating and Editing Shapes via Messages")

chapter.p: After selection, press Caps Lock to turn on Picster mode.
Picster offers a variety of drawing tools. Once Picster mode is on (by pressing Caps Lock), you will see the name of the current drawing tool displayed in red on the top-left corner of the canvas.

chapter.h2: Creating and Editing Shapes via Messages
chapter.p: Picster is integrated in the MaxScore API. The MaxScore abstraction can receives messages for the creation of shapes. These messages have the same result as drawing the shapes by hand, i.e. select the elements the shapes are supposed to be attached to first and set properties before the shapes are created.

chapter.p: When a shaped is clicked on, a red bounding rectangle will appear and the shape can be moved by dragging the rectangle to another location. Should shapes overlap, the “covered” shapes can be selected by repeatedly ctrl-clicking on them. The bounding rectangle will change its shape accordingly. Selected shapes can be deleted with the delete key.
chapter.i: Figure 5. Clicking on an object will selected it. It can now be moved, deleted or edited.
Figure 6 and 7: Select overlapping shapes by ctrl-clicking on the canvas
chapter.p: A shape can be copied, cut and pasted and thus attached to a different score element. Use the c, x and v keys in Picster mode, but be aware of the fact that in order to select another score element, Picster mode needs to be first toggled off. Once the element is selected, Picster mode should to be activated again.

Once a shape is selected it can also be edited after pressing the e (“edit”) key. This will open a text editor showing the properties of the shape in JSON format. The changes can be finalized by pressing the u (“update”) key. Note that if the fill property is supposed to be changed from fill to stroke or vice versa, the id (2nd line) of the shape will also need to be changed in order to take effect, i.e. a paintrect will have to be renamed to framerect, a paintoval to frameoval and so on.
chapter.i: Figure 8: Changes in the editor will take effect after closing the window and pressing the u key.
Figure 9: Changing the "transform" property for example to [ 0.5, 0, 0, 0.5, 0, 0 ] will shrink the image to half its size.
chapter.p: You can add an expression to a shape if you want the expression to be sent when you either click on a shape (all types), or click on the note/interval the shape is attached to. Note and interval will also play their expressions during playback.
An expression is a sub dictionary which contains four keys:

ul.li: message: the message to be sent, e.g. sfplay
value: value of the message, e.g. snare.mp3
